messageBody:
Cedric Beust wrote:

> That's not what I was saying. I am sure your code won't crash if the method
> is called without these prerequisites, it's just that it won't be doing
> anything useful (no-op or throwing an exception), so testing it in these
> conditions will be useless: you need to set up these prerequisites before
> you invoke the method.

Properly designed public methods rarely have prerequisites. Exceptions
are normally only used for exceptional conditions in the environment (in
which case they're checked exceptions) or precondition violations (in
which case they;re runtime exceptions).


> Seriously, can you take any two method invocations following each other in
> your code, swap them, and your code still works?!?

The code still does something reasonable from the standpoint of the
object. Obviously the algorithm may be changed. For instance, I can call
drawLine before drawRect, in which case the rect is drawn on top of the
line if they overlap, or I can call them in the reverse order in which
case the line is drawn on top. But from the perspective of a Graphics
object neither order is wrong.

The problem comes about when people design APIs that require something
like g.initializeContext(), g.setColor, and g.setFont before I'm allowed
to call g.drawLine. Any initialization that's necessary for an object to
get into its correct state should be performed in the constructor.

Complicated sequences of code execution are relics of procedural
thinking. In object oriented programming we pass messages to objects. We
may send any message to any object at any time. Which messages we send
when depends on what we want the objects to do. However, good objects
behave according to spec regardless of the order in which the methods
are invoked. They do not say some method sequences are legal and some
are illegal. This is because the classes and objects are the fundamental
units, not the functions and algorithms. This is the difference between
object oriented programming and procedural programming.
